Botchan (Master Darling) / Kin-nosuke Natsume 著

坊っちゃん / 夏目漱石 著 / Yasotaro Morri 訳

Annotator: 高橋真弓

英語文を消す 日本語文を消す

オリジナル:英語文&日本語文 / 対訳データ / このページにある対訳文について 6 of Botchan (Master Darling)

One should know better by my appearance.
大抵（たいてい）はなりや様子でも分る。
Any one who aspires to be a patron of art is usually pictured,--you may see in any drawing,--with either a hood on his head, or carrying a tanzaku[3] in his hand.
風流人なんていうものは、画（え）を見ても、頭巾（ずきん）を被（かぶ）るか短冊（たんざく）を持ってるものだ。
The fellow who calls me a connoisseur of art and pretends to mean it, may be surely as crooked as a dog's hind legs.
このおれを風流人だなどと真面目に云うのはただの曲者（くせもの）じゃない。
I told him I did not like such art-stuff, which is usually favored by retired people.
おれはそんな呑気（のんき）な隠居（いんきょ）のやるような事は嫌（きら）いだと云ったら、
He laughed, and remarking that that nobody liked it at first, but once in it, will find it so fascinating that he will hardly get over it, served tea for himself and drank it in a grotesque manner.
亭主はへへへへと笑いながら、いえ始めから好きなものは、どなたもございませんが、いったんこの道にはいるとなかなか出られませんと一人で茶を注いで妙な手付（てつき）をして飲んでいる。
I may say that I had asked him the night before to buy some tea for me, but I did not like such a bitter, heavy kind.
実はゆうべ茶を買ってくれと頼（たの）んでおいたのだが、こんな苦い濃（こ）い茶はいやだ。
One swallow seemed to act right on my stomach.
一杯（ぱい）飲むと胃に答えるような気がする。
I told him to buy a kind not so bitter as that, and he answered "All right, Sir," and drank another cup.
今度からもっと苦くないのを買ってくれと云ったら、かしこまりましたとまた一杯しぼって飲んだ。
The fellow seemed never to know of having enough of anything so long as it was another man's.
人の茶だと思って無暗（むやみ）に飲む奴（やつ）だ。
After he left the room, I prepared for the morrow and went to bed.
主人が引き下がってから、明日の下読（したよみ）をしてすぐ寝（ね）てしまった。



[Footnote 3: A tanzaku is a long, narrow strip of stiff paper on which a Japanese poem is written.]



Everyday thereafter I attended at the school and worked as per regulations.
それから毎日毎日学校へ出ては規則通り働く、
Every day on my return, the boss came to my room with the same old "Let me serve you tea."
毎日毎日帰って来ると主人がお茶を入れましょうと出てくる。
In about a week I understood the school in a general way, and had my own idea as to the personality of the boss and his wife.
一週間ばかりしたら学校の様子もひと通りは飲み込めたし、宿の夫婦の人物も大概（たいがい）は分った。
I heard from one of my fellow teachers that the first week to one month after the receipt of the appointment worried them most as to whether they had been favorably received among the students.
ほかの教師に聞いてみると辞令を受けて一週間から一ヶ月ぐらいの間は自分の評判がいいだろうか、悪（わ）るいだろうか非常に気に掛（か）かるそうであるが、
I never felt anything on that score.
おれは一向そんな感じはなかった。
Blunders in the class room once in a while caused me chagrin, but in about half an hour everything would clear out of my head.
教場で折々しくじるとその時だけはやな心持ちだが三十分ばかり立つと奇麗（きれい）に消えてしまう。
I am a fellow who, by nature, can't be worrying long about[F] anything even if I try to.
おれは何事によらず長く心配しようと思っても心配が出来ない男だ。
I was absolutely indifferent as how my blunders in the class room affected the students, or how much further they affected the principal or the head-teacher.
教場のしくじりが生徒にどんな影響（えいきょう）を与（あた）えて、その影響が校長や教頭にどんな反応を呈（てい）するかまるで無頓着（むとんじゃく）であった。
As I mentioned before, I am not a fellow of much audacity to speak of, but I am quick to give up anything when I see its finish.
おれは前に云う通りあまり度胸の据（すわ）った男ではないのだが、思い切りはすこぶるいい人間である。
I had resolved to go elsewhere at once if the school did not suit me.
この学校がいけなければすぐどっかへ行（ゆ）く覚悟（かくご）でいたから、
In consequence, neither Badger nor Red Shirt wielded any influence over me.
狸（たぬき）も赤シャツも、ちっとも恐（おそろ）しくはなかった。
And still less did I feel like coaxing or coddling the youngsters in the class room.
まして教場の小僧（こぞう）共なんかには愛嬌（あいきょう）もお世辞も使う気になれなかった。
So far it was O.K. with the school, but not so easy as that at my boarding house.
学校はそれでいいのだが下宿の方はそうはいかなかった。
I could have stood it if it had been only the boss coming to my room after my tea.
亭主が茶を飲みに来るだけなら我慢もするが、
But he would fetch many things to my room.
いろいろな者を持ってくる。
First time he brought in seals.[4]
始めに持って来たのは何でも印材で、
He displayed about ten of them before me and persuaded me to buy them for three yen, which was very cheap, he said.
十（とお）ばかり並（なら）べておいて、みんなで三円なら安い物だお買いなさいと云う。
Did he take me for a third rate painter making a round of the country?
田舎巡（いなかまわ）りのヘボ絵師じゃあるまいし、
I told him I did not want them.
そんなものは入らないと云ったら、
Next time he brought in a panel picture of flowers and birds, drawn by one Kazan or somebody.
今度は華山（かざん）とか何とか云う男の花鳥の掛物（かけもの）をもって来た。
He hung it against the wall of the alcove and asked me if it was not well done, and I echoed it looked well done.
自分で床（とこ）の間（ま）へかけて、いい出来じゃありませんかと云うから、そうかなと好加減（いいかげん）に挨拶（あいさつ）をすると、
Then he started lecturing about Kazan, that there are two Kazans, one is Kazan something and the other is Kazan anything, and that this picture was the work of that Kazan something.
華山には二人（ふたり）ある、一人は何とか華山で、一人は何とか華山ですが、この幅（ふく）はその何とか華山の方だと、
After this nonsensical lecture, he insisted that he would make it fifteen yen for me to buy it.
くだらない講釈をしたあとで、どうです、あなたなら十五円にしておきます。 お買いなさいと催促（さいそく）をする。
I declined the offer saying that I was shy of the money.
金がないと断わると、
"You can pay any time." He was insistent.
金なんか、いつでもようございますとなかなか頑固（がんこ）だ。
[Footnote 4: Artists have several seals of stone with which to stamp on the picture they draw as a guarantee of their personal work or for identification. The shape and kind of seals are quite a hobby among artists, and sales or exchange are of common occurrence.]



I settled him by telling him of my having no intention of purchasing it even if I had the necessary money.
金があつても買わないんだと、その時は追っ払（ぱら）っちまった。
Again next time, he yanked in a big writing stone slab about the size of a ridge-tile.
その次には鬼瓦（おにがわら）ぐらいな大硯（おおすずり）を担ぎ込んだ。
"This is a tankei,"[5] he said.
これは端渓（たんけい）です、
As he "tankeied" two or three times, I asked for fun what was a tankei.
端渓ですと二遍（へん）も三遍も端渓がるから、面白半分に端渓た何だいと聞いたら、
Right away he commenced lecturing on the subject.
すぐ講釈を始め出した。
"There are the upper, the middle and the lower stratum in tankei," he said.
端渓には上層中層下層とあって、
"Most of tankei slabs to-day are made from the upper stratum," he continued,
今時のものはみんな上層ですが、
"but this one is surely from the middle stratum.
これはたしかに中層です、
Look at this 'gan.'[6]
この眼（がん）をご覧なさい。
'Tis certainly rare to have three 'gans' like this.
眼が三つあるのは珍（めず）らしい。
The ink-cake grates smoothly on it.
溌墨（はつぼく）の具合も至極よろしい、
Try it, sir,"
試してご覧なさいと、
--and he pushed it towards me.
おれの前へ大きな硯を突（つ）きつける。
I asked him how much, and he answered that on account of its owner having brought it from China and wishing to sell if as soon as possible, he would make it very cheap, that I could have it for thirty yen.
いくらだと聞くと、持主が支那（しな）から持って帰って来て是非売りたいと云いますから、お安くして三十円にしておきましょうと云う。
I was sure he was a fool.
この男は馬鹿（ばか）に相違（そうい）ない。
I seemed to be able to get through the school somehow, but I would soon give out if this "curio siege" kept on long.
学校の方はどうかこうか無事に勤まりそうだが、こう骨董責（こっとうぜめ）に逢（あ）ってはとても長く続きそうにない。



[Footnote 5: Tankei is the name of a place in China where a certain kind of stone suitable for writing purposes was produced.] [Footnote 6: "Gan" may be understood as a kind of natural mark on the stone peculiar to the stone from Tankei.]



Shortly afterwards, I began to get sick of the school.
そのうち学校もいやになった。　　
One certain night, while I was strolling about a street named Omachi, I happened to notice a sign of noodles below of which was annotated "Tokyo" in the house next to the post office.
ある日の晩大町（おおまち）と云う所を散歩していたら郵便局の隣（とな）りに蕎麦（そば）とかいて、下に東京と注を加えた看板があった。
I am very fond of noodles.
おれは蕎麦が大好きである。
While I was in Tokyo, if I passed by a noodle house and smelled the seasoning spices, I felt uncontrollable temptation to go inside at any cost.
東京に居（お）った時でも蕎麦屋の前を通って薬味の香（にお）いをかぐと、どうしても暖簾（のれん）がくぐりたくなった。
Up to this time I had forgotten the noodle on account of mathematics and antique curios, but since I had seen thus the sign of noodles, I could hardly pass it by unnoticed.
今日までは数学と骨董で蕎麦を忘れていたが、こうして看板を見ると素通りが出来なくなる。
So availing myself of this opportunity, I went in.
ついでだから一杯食って行こうと思って上がり込んだ。
It was not quite up to what I had judged by the sign.
見ると看板ほどでもない。
Since it claimed to follow the Tokyo style, they should have tidied up a little bit about the room.
東京と断（こと）わる以上はもう少し奇麗にしそうなものだが、
They did not either know Tokyo or have the means,--I did not know which, but the room was miserably dirty.
東京を知らないのか、金がないのか、滅法（めっぽう）きたない。
The floor-mats had all seen better days and felt shaggy with sandy dust.
畳（たたみ）は色が変ってお負けに砂でざらざらしている。
The sootcovered walls defied the blackest black.
壁（かべ）は煤（すす）で真黒（まっくろ）だ。
The ceiling was not only smoked by the lamp black, but was so low as to force one involuntarily bend down his neck.
天井（てんじょう）はランプの油烟（ゆえん）で燻（くす）ぼってるのみか、低くって、思わず首を縮めるくらいだ。
Only the price-list, on which was glaringly written "Noodles" and which was pasted on the wall, was entirely new.
ただ麗々と蕎麦の名前をかいて張り付けたねだん付けだけは全く新しい。
I was certain that they bought an old house and opened the business just two or three days before.
何でも古いうちを買って二三日（にさんち）前から開業したに違（ちが）いなかろう。
At the head of the price-list appeared "tempura" (noodles served with shrimp fried in batter).
ねだん付の第一号に天麩羅（てんぷら）とある。
"Say, fetch me some tempura," I ordered in a loud voice.
おい天麩羅を持ってこいと大きな声を出した。
Then three fellows who had been making a chewing noise together in a corner, looked in my direction.
するとこの時まで隅（すみ）の方に三人かたまって、何かつるつる、ちゅうちゅう食ってた連中（れんじゅう）が、ひとしくおれの方を見た。
As the room was dark I did not notice them at first. But when we looked at each other, I found them all to be boys in our school.
部屋（へや）が暗いので、ちょっと気がつかなかったが顔を合せると、みんな学校の生徒である。
They "how d'ye do'd" me and I acknowledged it.
先方で挨拶（あいさつ）をしたから、おれも挨拶をした。
That night, having come across the noodle after so long a time, it tasted so fine that I ate four bowls.
その晩は久（ひさ）し振（ぶり）に蕎麦を食ったので、旨（うま）かったから天麩羅を四杯平（たいら）げた。
The next day as I entered the class room quite unconcernedly, I saw on the black board written in letters so large as to take up the whole space; "Professor Tempura."
翌日何の気もなく教場へはいると、黒板一杯ぐらいな大きな字で、天麩羅先生とかいてある。
The boys all glanced at my face and made merry hee-haws at my cost.
おれの顔を見てみんなわあと笑った。
It was so absurd that I asked them if it was in any way funny for me to eat tempura noodle.
おれは馬鹿馬鹿しいから、天麩羅を食っちゃ可笑（おか）しいかと聞いた。
Thereupon one of them said, --"But four bowls is too much."
すると生徒の一人（ひとり）が、しかし四杯は過ぎるぞな、もし、と云った。
What did they care if I ate four bowls or five as long as I paid it with my own money,--and speedily finishing up my class, I returned to the teachers' room.
四杯食おうが五杯食おうがおれの銭でおれが食うのに文句があるもんかと、さっさと講義を済まして控所へ帰って来た。
After tenminutes' recess, I went to the next class, and there on the black board was newly written quite as large as before; "Four bowls of tempura noodles, but don't laugh."
十分立って次の教場へ出ると一つ天麩羅四杯なり。 但（ただ）し笑うべからず。 と黒板にかいてある。
The first one did not arouse any ill-temper in me, but this time it made me feel irritating mad.
さっきは別に腹も立たなかったが今度は癪（しゃく）に障（さわ）った。
A joke carried too far becomes mischievous.
冗談（じょうだん）も度を過ごせばいたずらだ。
It is like the undue jealousy of some women who, like coal, look black and suggest flames.
焼餅（やきもち）の黒焦（くろこげ）のようなもので
Nobody likes it.
誰（だれ）も賞（ほ）め手はない。
These country simpletons, unable to differentiate upon so delicate a boundary, would seem to be bent on pushing everything to the limit.
田舎者はこの呼吸が分からないからどこまで押（お）して行っても構わないと云う了見（りょうけん）だろう。
As they lived in such a narrow town where one has no more to see if he goes on strolling about for one hour, and as they were capable of doing nothing better, they were trumpeting aloud this tempura incident in quite as serious a manner as the Russo-Japanese war.
一時間あるくと見物する町もないような狭（せま）い都に住んで、外に何にも芸がないから、天麩羅事件を日露（にちろ）戦争のように触（ふ）れちらかすんだろう。
What a bunch of miserable pups!
憐（あわ）れな奴等（やつら）だ。
It is because they are raised in this fashion from their boyhood that there are many punies who, like the dwarf maple tree in the flower pot, mature gnarled and twisted.
小供の時から、こんなに教育されるから、いやにひねっこびた、植木鉢（うえきばち）の楓（かえで）みたような小人（しょうじん）が出来るんだ。
I have no objection to laugh myself with others over innocent jokes.
無邪気（むじゃき）ならいっしょに笑ってもいいが、
But how's this?
こりゃなんだ。
Boys as they are, they showed a "poisonous temper."
小供の癖（くせ）に乙（おつ）に毒気を持ってる。
Silently erasing off "tempura" from the board, I questioned them if they thought such mischief interesting, that this was a cowardly joke
おれはだまって、天麩羅を消して、こんないたずらが面白いか、卑怯（ひきょう）な冗談だ。
and if they knew the meaning of "cowardice."
君等は卑怯と云う意味を知ってるか、と云ったら、
Some of them answered that to get angry on being laughed at over one's own doing, was cowardice.
自分がした事を笑われて怒（おこ）るのが卑怯じゃろうがな、もしと答えた奴がある。
What made them so disgusting as this?
やな奴だ。
